HK's  virus  tally  81  with  7  new  infections. The  Hospital  Authority  said  the  newly  infected  people  include  a  businessman,  two  visitors  to  a  local  temple  and  four  passengers  from  the  Diamond  Princess.

Foreign  ministry:  LegCo  election  delayed  for  HK  people's  safety. Foreign  Ministry  spokesperson  Wang  Wenbin  said  no  foreign  government,  organization  or  individual  has  the  right  to  interfere  in  the  LegCo  election.

Mainland  enterprises  in  the  SAR  vow  not  to  sack  staff. The  move  is  in  response  to  a  call  by  the  Hong  Kong  Coalition,  which  has  vowed  to  revive  HK's  battered  economy  and  help  new  graduates  find  employment..

Bond  Connect  sees  record-high  trading  volume  in  August. Trading  volume  under  the  Bond  Connect  program  reached  338.6  billion  yuan  in  August,  according  to  the  China  Foreign  Exchange  Trade  System.

National  knowledge  quiz  draws  record  no.  of  HK  contestants. More  than  5,000  students  from  160  schools  and  universities  participated  in  the  9th  Hong  Kong  National  Knowledge  Contest  –  the  city's  largest  such  events.
Arson  attacks  on  HK  courts  widely  condemned. Firebombing  decried  as  challenge  to  rule  of  law,  unacceptable  in  society

Meituan-Dianping  moves  to  pare  losses  in  new  sectors. Meituan-Dianping  says  it  will  still  focus  on  its  core  operations  this  year  and  strive  to  narrow  the  losses  in  new  sectors  like  bike-sharing.

HK  private  sector  contracts  faster  in  Aug  as  PMI  falls  to  44. Private  sector  economy  contracted  at  a  faster  pace  in  August  led  by  sharper  declines  in  output  and  new  orders  amid  tighter  social  distancing  restrictions.

Public  urged  to  stay  home  as  HK  sees  59  new  cases. Forty  of  the  new  cases  confirmed  Sunday,  including  18  students  returning  from  the  US  and  the  UK,  had  traveled  overseas  during  the  incubation  period.
Tencent  sell-off  nears  US$100b  as  stock  loses  key  support. Tencent  is  now  trading  below  the  key  level  of  HK$320  that  supported  its  shares  on  three  occasions  this  year.

Commerce  secretary  stresses  HK's  free  trade  policy  in  US. Edward  Yau  Tang-wah  said  on  Wednesday  that  Hong  Kong  vigorously  pursues  a  free  trade  policy  and  firmly  believes  in  multilateral  trading  system.

As  HK  economy  sinks,  scant  liquidity  underpins  dollar. The  city's  economy  shrank  8.9  percent  in  the  first  quarter,  the  worst  drop  in  data  going  back  to  1974,  according  to  the  HK  Census  and  Statistics  Department.

HK  establishes  committee  for  safeguarding  national  security. Edwina  Lau  Chi-wai  was  appointed  as  the  deputy  commissioner  of  the  Hong  Kong  Police  Force  to  lead  a  department  that  is  dealing  with  national  security  cases.
HK  doing  ‘reasonably  well’  in  virus  control,  says  former  WHO  adviser. But  professor  Keiji  Fukuda  warned  that  COVID-19  is  not  something  that  will  last  for  just  a  few  weeks.

HK  protests:  How  violence  escalates. China  Daily  takes  a  look  at  the  escalation  of  violence  unleashed  by  the  radicals,  whose  weapons  of  choice  varied  from  umbrellas  to  gasoline  bombs.

Industry  leaders  praise  tax  concessions  for  maritime  businesses. ​The  logistics  and  transportation  sector  said  the  tax  concessions  would  fortify  Hong  Kong’s  status  as  a  strategic  hub  in  intra-Asia  trade.
Peer  influence  among  factors  blamed  in  HK. An  expert  said  dialogue  can  help  break  the  city's  current  deadlock  but  it  will  be  a  difficult  task.
HK-listed  mainland  banks  report  interim  results. BOC  Hong  Kong  (Holdings)  posted  a  meager  0.2  percent  increase  in  net  profit  to  17.52  billion  yuan.

HK  universities  urged  to  play  bigger  role  in  Bay  Area. Delegates  at  the  region's  first  education  forum  encourage  SAR  institutions  to  overcome  space  woes  by  setting  up  satellite  campuses.
Tutoring  centers  in  HK  struggle  for  survival  amid  pandemic. A  small  tutoring  center  in  Tsuen  Wan  district  has  seen  a  90%  drop  in  students  after  the  coronavirus  outbreak.

Bay  Area  'best  chance  for  youth  to  realize  dreams'. An  entrepreneur  called  for  more  social  services  for  Hong  Kong  and  Macao  residents  relocating  to  cities  in  Bay  Area,  especially  young  talents  and  the  elderly.

HSBC  pledges  more  investments  in  the  mainland. The  bank  on  Friday  announced  it  was  starting  a  new  service  to  provide  customers  in  the  mainland  with  digital  wealth  and  insurance  planning  services.

HK  adding  new  medical  facilities  as  city  reports  6  new  virus  cases. With  the  central  govt's  support,  HK  is  building  a  makeshift  hospital  and  adding  new  treatment  facilities  in  AsiaWorld-Expo  in  case  of  a  winter  virus  outbreak.
Greater  Bay  Area  backs  TCM  going  global. Three  institutions  will  pool  their  resources  and  talent,  hoping  to  unearth  potent  TCM  treatments  for  autoimmune  diseases.

Clawing  back  a  living  in    an  'ice  age'  for  retailers. The  soured  business  climate  has  led  to  change  of  business  modes  as  well  as  a  major  shift  in  the  commercial  property  market.

Mainland  rebuts  false  claim  that  HK  has  'separation  of  powers’. A  spokesperson  for  the  Hong  Kong  and  Macao  Affairs  Office  of  the  State  Council  said  it  is  wrong  to  state  that  the  HKSAR  exercises  "separation  of  powers".

Private  sector  has  a  big  role  as  sustainable  investing  takes  root. Ronie  Mak,  managing  director  of  family  office  RS  Group,  said  Hong  Kong  has  seen  a  huge  development  in  concerning  awareness  in  impact  investing  in  2018.

Fan  saddened  by  ugly  scenes  in  LegCo. Former  president  of  the  Legislative  Council  Rita  Fan  suggests  bypassing  the  bills  committee  and  taking  the  extradition  bill  to  a  full  LegCo  meeting.
Hong  Kong  shares  close  0.16%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  43.89  points,  or  0.16  percent,  to  27,946.32  points  on  Friday.
HK  to  get  European  flower  park. The  European-themed  Kaleido  Park  will  be  the  first-of-its-kind  in  the  city,  offering  a  unique  horticultural  experience  through  floral  displays.
Hong  Kong  commemorates  late  premier  Zhou  Enlai. An  exhibition  highlighting  late  premier  Zhou  Enlai’s  life  was  launched  on  Wednesday.

Vice-premier:  Down-to-earth  work  needed  for  Bay  Area. Han  Zheng  made  the  remarks  while  chairing  the  second  plenary  meeting  of  the  leading  group  for  the  development  of  the  Greater  Bay  Area.
Accountants  'pessimistic'  about  HK  economy. Accounting  and  finance  professionals  are  pessimistic  about  Hong  Kong's  economic  performance  in  2019,  a  survey  shows.
CE:  We'll  push  ahead  with  extradition  law  amendments. CE  Carrie  Lam  calls  for  extradition  law  revision  to  be  passed  by  July  to  plug  legal  loopholes.
Wang  vows  deeper  cooperation  with  SAR  government. Joint  efforts  for  the  future  prosperity  of  the  HKSAR  have  been  fruitful  and  will  be  stepped  up,  said  liaison  chief.

Tough  times  for  retailers  as  violent  protests  go  on. For  the  first  half  of  2019,  it  was  estimated  that  the  value  of  retail  sales  fell  2.6  percent  compared  with  the  same  period  the  previous  year.

CE  leaves  for  official  visit  to  Switzerland,  to  attend  WEF. Carrie  Lam  will  meet  with  senior  government  officials,  business  leaders  and  professionals  in  Switzerland  besides  attending  the  Davos  forum.
Civic  leaders  back  comments  by  central  govt  authorities. HK  political  and  civic  leaders  convinced  of  urgency  to  support  SAR  govt,  police  in  ending  violence.

Hong  Kong  parents  want  refunds  as  schools  shut  for  months. The  city’s  school-aged  children  are  expected  to  miss  about  13  weeks  of  classes  due  to  government-mandated  shutdowns.

Carrie  Lam  shoots  down  reshuffle  rumor,  to  visit  Beijing. The  Hong  Kong  CE  urged  people  to  stop  spreading  rumors  and  speculating  about  a  reshuffle  involving  principal  officials  and  the  Executive  Council.
Typhoon:  Flooding,  building  damages  reported  in  HK,  Macao. Winds  started  to  weaken  in  Hong  Kong  as  “super  typhoon”  Mangkhut  started  to  depart  the  city  in  the  afternoon.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.59%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  162.93  points,  or  0.59  percent,  to  27,241.34  points.

Hong  Kong  mourns  for  lives  lost  to  COVID-19. Hong  Kong's  government  officials  and  residents  observed  a  three-minute  silence  on  Saturday  to  mourn  those  to  lost  their  lives  in  the  epidemic  fight.
HK  Technology  Talent  Scheme  opens  for  application. The  scheme  spearheads  two  initiatives  –  a  Postdoctoral  Hub  program  and  a  Reindustrialization  and  Technology  Training  Program.

SAR's  sci-tech  sector  gets  a  timely  boost. Hong  Kong  scientists  said  the  central  govt's  latest  policies  are  set  to  help  develop  the  Greater  Bay  Area  into  a  global  innovation  and  technology  hub.

People  in  HK  'eager  to  know  about  PLA'. DAB  survey  finds  73  percent  seek  greater  knowledge  of  the  military  while  nearly  half  believe  city's  youth  should  have  a  chance  to  serve.

Liaison  Office  joins  HK's  annual  walk  for  charity. It  was  the  first  time  the  liaison  office  has  participated  in  the  Community  Chest  charity  walk,  in  the  hope  of  bringing  the  office  and  its  staff  closer  to  the  public.

HK,  Macao  experts  invited  to  evaluation  on  C919  aircraft. Civil  aviation  experts  from  Hong  Kong  and  Macao  have  been  invited  to  participate  in  the  operational  evaluation  of  C919  aircraft.

Developers  speak  up  against  violence. Among  the  signatories  of  the  statement  are  CK  Asset  Holdings,  New  World  Development,  Sun  Hung  Kai  Properties,  and  Henderson  Land  Development.

The  legacy  of  a  patriotic  businessman. Ian  Fok  Chun-wan  pays  tribute  to  his  father  Henry  Fok  Ying-tung,  who  was  a  pioneer  of  China's  economic  reform  and  opening-up  to  the  outside  world.

Track  Cycling  World  Cup  leg  to  go  ahead  in  HK  this  weekend. The  track  cycling  World  Cup  leg  in  Hong  Kong  this  weekend  will  go  ahead  as  planned  in  the  New  Territories  of  the  city  from  Nov.  29  to  Dec.  1.

ICAC  head  calls  for  clean,  fair  district  council  election. As  of  Thursday,  the  ICAC  has  received  77  complaints  in  relation  to  the  election  slated  for  Nov  24,  said  ICAC  Commissioner  Simon  Peh.
HK  residents  come  out  to  clear  roads. People  of  various  age  groups  joined  hands  to  remove  barricades  and  debris  by  hand  on  Pok  Fu  Lam  Road  and  adjacent  Bonham  Road.

Nine  found  guilty  of  roles  in  2014  Occupy  protests. According  to  Hong  Kong's  Crimes  Ordinance  and  the  Criminal  Procedure  Ordinance,  each  charge  carries  up  to  seven  years  in  prison.

Leaders  of  SARs  mourn  death  of  Macao  Liaison  Office  chief. Political  heavyweights  in  the  Macao  and  Hong  Kong  SARs  sent  condolences  over  the  death  of  Zheng  Xiaosong,  who  died  Saturday  night  after  falling  from  his  flat.

Protection  of  endangered  dolphins  a  priority  in  epic  bridge  project. The  central  government  has  prioritized  protection  of  the  dolphin  following  the  construction  of  the  Hong  Kong-Zhuhai-Macao  Bridge  that  started  in  2009.
Innovation  push  to  boost  HK’s  status  as  financial  hub. ​The  Bay  Area’s  focus  on  developing  new  technologies  will  help  HK  compete  better  on  the  world  stage.

Electoral  Affairs  Commission  respects  govt  decision  to  delay  poll. The  Electoral  Affairs  Commission  has  expressed  understanding  and  respect  over  the  decision  by  the  HKSAR  government  to  postpone  the  LegCo  election  amid  concern  about  the  virus.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.53%  lower. The  benchmark  Hang  Seng  Index  traded  between  24,602.11  and  24,872.52.  Turnover  totaled  HK$130.52  billion  (about  US$16.84  billion).

NPC  Standing  Committee  reviews  HK  security  legislation. The  Standing  Committee  of  National  People's  Congress  started  to  review  the  draft  of  the  national  security  law  for  HK  during  its  session  that  began  Thursday.

Tributes  pour  in  for  prominent  philanthropist  in  HK. Renowned  Hong  Kong  philanthropist  and  prominent  industrialist  Tin  Ka-ping  died  at  the  age  of  99  in  the  city  on  Tuesday  morning.

Opposition  politicians  blasted  for  disseminating  fake  news. Alvin  Yeung  and  Alan  Leong  Kah-kit  were  criticized  by  netizens  for  misleading  the  public  in  trying  to  tarnish  the  police  image  with  lies.

HK  unrest:  HSBC  stops  weekend  overnight  services  at  some  ATMs. HSBC  said  it  will  suspend  overnight  services  at  19  ATM  clusters  on  weekends  and  public  holidays,  after  its  branches  and  ATMs  were  targeted  during  protests.

Mainland  companies  reconsider  IPOs  as  HK  unrest  persists. One  company  has  scrapped  preliminary  preparations  for  an  IPO  in  HK  while  2  others  are  considering  the  same  move,  people  familiar  with  the  matter  said.
HK  holds  1st  exhibition  on  national  security. Hong  Kong  is  holding  its  first  themed  exhibition  on  national  security  from  April  15  to  30.

HKSAR  govt  committed  to  dialogues  to  resolve  differences. Chief  Secretary  for  Administration  Matthew  Cheung  said  that  the  government  will  have  more  dialogues  with  all  sectors  to  resolve  differences.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.87%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  531.21  points,  or  1.87  percent,  to  27,900.84  points.

Belt  and  Road  Initiative  gains  more  recognition  globally. A  3,000-km  corridor,  which  starts  from  China's  Kashgar  in  the  west  and  ends  at  Pakistan's  Gwadar,  is  transforming  Pakistan's  energy  sector.

Greater  Bay  Area  to  remain  key  market  for  Singapore  firms. Singapore  and  China's  southern  Guangdong  will  emerge  from  the  COVID-19  pandemic  stronger,  according  to  a  joint  statement  released  on  Monday.
Hong  Kong  woman  killed  while  climbing  Table  Mountain. Another  woman,  also  from  Hong  Kong,  was  slightly  injured  in  Monday's  accident  in  Cape  Town.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.01%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  2.01  points,  or  0.01  percent,  to  28,961.6  points.
HK  fines  Goldman  Sachs  record  US$350m  over  1MDB  failings. It  was  the  largest  single  fine  ever  levied  by  Hong  Kong's  market  watchdog  Securities  and  Futures  Commission.

HK  govt  clarifies  false  claims  on  Sino-British  Joint  Declaration. The  clarification  came  after  a  group  claimed  that  the  fact  universal  suffrage  has  yet  to  be  implemented  in  HK  is  a  "serious  violation  of  the  declaration.
HK  eyes  new  trading  rules,  adding  rebates  to  spur  volume. The  exchange  operator  is  eyeing  changes  as  it  battles  for  business  with  its  international  rivals.

Hong  Kong's  currency  peg  defense  increases  to  US$760m. The  aggregate  balance,  a  measure  of  interbank  liquidity,  will  increase  to  HK$64.97  billion  on  April  24,  2020,  a  HKMA  spokesman  said.

Speech  by  CE  at  Bay  Area  symposium  in  Tokyo. Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  delivered  a  keynote  speech  at  the  Symposium  on  the  Guangdong-Hong  Kong-Macao  Greater  Bay  Area  in  Tokyo  on  Tuesday.

Singapore  companies  abandon  home  to  list  in  Hong  Kong. In  2019,  10  Singapore  firms  debuted  in  Hong  Kong,  raising  US$155  million,  a  25  percent  increase  from  2018,  according  to  data  compiled  by  Bloomberg.

HK  Customs  probes  misdeclared  surgical  masks. Hong  Kong  Customs  launched  an  investigation  after  surgical  masks  suspected  of  bearing  a  false  origin  claim  were  supplied  to  the  government.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.90%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  239.01  points,  or  0.90  percent,  to  26,906.72  points.

China  urges  UK  to  stop  meddling  in  HKSAR  affairs. ​Foreign  Ministry  spokesperson  Geng  Shuang  made  the  remarks  at  a  press  briefing  in  response  to  Britain's  latest  "Six-Monthly  Report  on  Hong  Kong."

HKUST’s  invention  to  speed  up  diagnoses  of  novel  coronavirus. Hong  Kong  scientists  have  developed  a  new  device  that  can  shorten  the  testing  time  for  the  novel  coronavirus  to  40  minutes  from  up  to  three  hours.

Hong  Kong  Exchange  proves  safe  bet  in  city’s  trying  times. Hong  Kong  Exchanges  &  Clearing  Ltd.  has  surged  46%  in  2020,  making  it  the  second-biggest  gainer  in  the  benchmark  Hang  Seng  Index.

Package  of  goodies,  sweeteners  wins  voices  of  support. The  support  gives  a  thumb-up  to  the  SAR  govt's  determination  to  ease  the  burdens  on  individuals  and  companies  under  the  faltering  local  economy.

Survey:  Bay  Area  businesses  to  see  improvement  in  Q3  recovery. Businesses  in  the  Guangdong-Hong  Kong-Macao  Greater  Bay  Area  are  expected  to  come  under  less  pressure  with  a  recovery  in  the  third  quarter  of  2020,  a  survey  shows.

National  security  law  'respects  HK  judicial  independence'. Carrie  Lam  stressed  that  the  proposed  national  security  law  won't  impair  the  HKSAR's  judicial  independence  and  its  high  degree  of  autonomy.

HK  police  find  gasoline  bomb  supplies  ahead  of  New  Year. Hong  Kong  police  found  six  jerrycans  of  gasoline  and  51  glass  bottles  on  a  hillside  at  a  residential  area  in  Wong  Tai  Sin  district,  Kowloon.

Peaceful  expression  of  views  urged. People  called  for  peaceful  expression  of  views,  and  reminded  the  public  that  exercising  freedom  of  expression  should  not  disrupt  other  people's  daily  lives.
Economists  propose  development  index  for  Bay  Area. Shenzhen's  former  vice-mayor  indicates  need  to  evaluate  and  analyze  development  as  city  cluster  advances.

Former  CE  says  decision  to  delay  poll  lawful,  reasonable. The  SAR  govt  has  the  duty  to  ensure  that  elections  are  held  in  a  fair  and  safe  environment,  said  former  chief  executive  Tung  Chee-hwa.
HK  firms  fail  to  walk  the  walk  on  technology. HSBC  survey  finds  companies  acknowledge  benefits  but  most  hang  back  from  digitizing  their  business.

At  least  5  dead,  over  30  injured  in  Tsing  Yi  car  crash. The  city's  Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  has  expressed  sadness  over  the  accident,  and  said  she  has  asked  relevant  bureaus  to  follow  up  on  the  incident.

Financial  Secretary  Chan  visits  Bay  Area  cities. Financial  Secretary  Paul  Chan  Mo-po  is
scheduled  to  visit  two  cities  in  the  Guangdong-Hong  Kong-Macao  Greater  Bay  Area  this  week.

There’s  just  no  place  like  home. Despite  a  year  of  unprecedented  street  protests,  the  current  economic  recession  and  the  coronavirus  shock,  HK's  housing  market  fundamentals  remain  sound.

HK  stocks  down  2%  as  tech,  financial  shares  slump. The  Hang  Seng  index  fell  2.0  percent,  to  25,840.34,  while  the  China  Enterprises  Index  lost  1.6  percent,  to  10,466.11  points.
CE:  National  security  legislation  protects  investors'  interests. Business  confidence  in  Hong  Kong  will  improve  as  the  place  will  be  safer,  Carrie  Lam  said.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.93%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  280.11  points,  or  0.93  percent,  to  29,839.45  points.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.91%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  551.03  points,  or  1.91  percent,  to  28,228.42  points.

IPCC  report  is  balanced  and  factual,  says  security  chief. Secretary  for  Security  John  Lee  Ka-chiu  said  the  report  was  "a  fair  reflection  of  facts  that  had  appeared  in  front  of  all  of  us  in  the  past  10  months".

Film  reproduces  National  Day  pageantry  on  big  screen  in  HK. A  movie  that  documented  the  grand  military  parade  and  public  parade  at  the  Tian'anmen  Square  in  Beijing  on  Oct  1  made  its  HK  debut  on  Wednesday.

Anti-mask  law  empowers  police  in  curbing  violence:  Tang  King-shing. Former  Hong  Kong  police  commissioner  says  anti-mask  law  helps  police  restore  law  and  order  in  city  as  so-called  "peaceful"  protesters  escalate  violence.

'No  noticeable  capital  outflow'  from  SAR  despite  unrest. James  Lau  said  HK  has  a  large  number  of  opportunities  to  collaborate  with  cities  in  Bay  Area  as  fintech  would  further  boost  HK's  edge  on  a  global  scale.

CUHK  establishes  Asia's  first  microbiota  transplantation  center. The  Faculty  of  Medicine  at  CUHK    announced  that  it  has  established  Asia's  first  and  Hong  Kong's  only  microbiota  transplantation  and  research  center.

HK  banks  offer  loan  help,  staff  perks  amid  virus  outbreak. Banks  in  Hong  Kong  are  considering  loan  relief  to  help  struggling  customers  and  businesses  as  the  coronavirus  outbreak  threatens  to  spread  in  the  city.

HK  official  urges  end  to  violence  ahead  of  district  council  poll. Constitutional  and  mainland  affairs  secretary  Patrick  Nip  urged  opposing  sides  to  work  together  for  the  Nov  24  election.

HK  mortgages  get  more  expensive  as  capital  costs  rise. Major  banks  initiated  a  flurry  of  mortgage  loan  rate  increases,  signaling  the  decade  of  ultra-low  interest  rates  may  soon  come  to  an  end.

Hong  Kong  Memories  2018:  Challenges  overcome. Data  breach,  disease  outbreaks,  natural  disasters…  Hong  Kong  dealt  with  it  all  in  2018.  In  the  second  part  of  Hong  Kong  Memories,  we  look  at  the  challenges  the  city  faced  and  overcame  in  the  past  year.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.47%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  115.24  points,  or  0.47  percent,  to  24,595.35  points  on  Friday.

Hong  Kong  confirms  1  new  COVID-19  case,  tally  at  1,197. The  new  case  involved  a  39-year-old  woman  who  came  to  Hong  Kong  from  the  Philippines,  according  to  the  Centre  for  Health  Protection.

HKMA  steps  in  to  defend  peg  for  first  time  since  August. The  HKMA  bought  HK$1.507  billion  of  local  currency    as  the  city’s  exchange  rate  fell  to  the  weak  end  of  its  trading  band  against  the  greenback.

HK  'strongly  disagrees'  with  US  report  on  trafficking  in  persons. A  HKSAR  govt  spokesman  stressed  that  the  latest  report  by  the  US  "contains  criticisms  not  founded  on  facts  and  allegations  not  supported  by  evidence."
Bay  Area  has  'key  role'  in  cutting  emissions. Chinas's  top  climate  change  negotiator  Xie  hopes  technology-focused  area  will  provide  innovative  renewable-energy  solutions.
Miriam  Lau:  Meeting  of  opposition  lawmakers  invalid. Veteran  lawmaker  says  this  is  because  bills  committee  on  fugitive  bill  was  held  without  LegCo  Secretariat  staff.
HK  has  'critical  business-services  role'  in  B&R. Addressing  initiative's  needs  will  be  important  driver  for  city's  economy,  commerce  secretary  says.

A  HK  doctor's  'nefarious  network'  sparks  market  inquiry. The  network  of  doctor-turned-financier  Roy  Cho  is  now  part  of  the  biggest  investigation  of  market  malfeasance  in  Hong  Kong's  history.

Drones:  HK  to  refine  regulation  as  complaints  double  in  2  years. In  April,  the  Civil  Aviation  Department  launched  a  three-month  public  consultation  on  six  key  proposals  regarding  the  unmanned  aircraft  system  regulatory  regime.
HK  deep  in  recession  as  GDP  dives  8.9%. The  8.9%  year-on-year  dive  in  GDP  was  the  biggest  fall  since  the  government  began  tracking  comparable  data  in  1974.

Civil  groups  urge  second  thoughts  on  poll  arrangements. The  Electoral  Affairs  Commission  was  urged  to  prioritize  the  elderly  for  the  Legislative  Council  election  on  September  6.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.20%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  51.14  points,  or  0.20  percent,  to  25,865.39  points.

Sha  Tin-Central  link's  first  section  to  open  early  2020. Tuen  Ma  Line  will  connect  Tuen  Mun  in  the  New  Territories  West  through  the  existing  West  Rail  Line  to  Ma  On  Shan  in  the  New  Territories  East.
HK  reports  11  new  virus  cases,  tally  reaches  5,280. The  fresh  infections  reported  on  Thursday  include  one  local  case  with  no  known  origin.
HK's  MTR  offers  HK$500m  concession  after  fare  rise. The  new  promotion  package  includes  discount  for  passengers  using  trains  and  green  minibuses.

HK  to  relax  dine-in,  mask  curbs  starting  Friday. HK  will  allow  dine-in  services  at  restaurants  till  9  pm  and  the  removal  of  masks  during  outdoor  exercise  from  Friday  as  virus  cases  in  the  city  dwindled.

Mainland  internet  firms  consider  secondary  listings  in  HK. More  of  such  firms  that  are  listed  in  the  US  may  mull  secondary  listings  in  HK  as  it  would  ease  regulatory  risks  and  expand  their  investor  base,  analysts  said.

First  of  HK's  new  online-only  banks  starts  operating. ZA  Bank  Ltd,  a  unit  of  China's  ZhongAn  Online  P&C  Insurance  Co,  is  one  of  the  eight  companies  that  were  issued  virtual  banking  licenses  in  Hong  Kong.

HK  govt:  Judicial  independence  guaranteed  under  Basic  Law. The  govt  said  there  could  be  no  question  of  the  National  Security  Law    affecting  the  city's  judicial  independence  and  the  smooth  operation  of  the  judicial  system.
Something  on  the  other  side  of  the  coin. Piles  of  unused  coins  left  at  home  can  now  be  handled  by  sorting  machines.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.19%  lower. The  benchmark  Hang  Seng  Index  traded  between  25,040.55  and  25,378.53.  Turnover  totaled  HK$103.32  billion  (about  US$13.33  billion).

China  to  impose  visa  restrictions  on  US  individuals  over  HKSAR. China  has  decided  to  impose  visa  curbs  on  US  individuals  who  have  behaved  egregiously  over  HK-related  issues,  a  Foreign  Ministry  spokesman  said.

HK  tour  guides  rush  for  practice  permit  in  Hengqin. More  than  500  tour  guides  and  leaders  from  HK  &  Macao  have  applied  for  the  permit  since  the  Guangdong  govt  announced  the  new  policy  last  week.
Carrie  Lam  backs  police'  media  registration  rules. The  chief  executive  said  the  move  was  an  “objective”  and  “open”  decision  that  ensures  all  media  can  be  treated  equally.

University  of  Chicago's  HK  campus  opens  its  doors. The  new  campus  will  be  home  for  the  university’s  faculty,  graduate  students  and  undergraduates  working  and  studying  in  Hong  Kong.

Q&A  on  NPC's  draft  decision  on  HK  national  security  legislation. Hong  Kong's  Tomorrow  Concern  Group  answers  20  questions  about  the  nation's  top  legislature's  decision  on  the  national  security  legislation  in  Hong  Kong.

DoJ:  No  undue  influence  behind  move  to  prosecute  Jimmy  Lai. The  Department  of  Justice  said  it  makes  each  prosecutorial  decision  based  on  evidence,  applicable  law  and  the  Prosecution  Code.

SARs'  youngsters  to  get  all-round  services. The  Guangdong-Hong  Kong-Macao  Greater  Bay  Area  Youth  Home  will  help  youths  working  and  living  in  the  Bay  Area  to  overcome  problems.

STAR,  HK  bourses  rival,  but  also  complement  each  other. STAR  market  could  be  a  formidable  rival  to  HK's  equity  market  as  more  technology  companies  would  turn  to  Shanghai's  new  venue  for  floatation.
Financial  secretary  confident  of  world  economic  recovery. Paul  Chan  says  geopolitical  tensions  between  the  US  and  China  remain  a  major  challenge.
First  suspect  charged  under  security  law. A  23-year-old  man  was  charged  on  Friday  with  terrorism  and  inciting  secession.
Home  prices,  pollution  hurt  HK  sustainability  ranking. ​The  city  fell  to  No  2  in  Asia  on  the  2018  Sustainable  Cities  Index,  compiled  by  Netherlands-based  firm  Arcadis.
Four  more  dengue  cases  reported. Three  men  and  one  woman  aged  between  18  and  76  are  receiving  treatment  Hong  Kong's  Centre  for  Health  Protection  (CHP)  said.
340,000  lined  Victoria  Harbour  to  watch  fireworks  show. Countdown  celebrations  were  also  held  in  Causeway  Bay,  Lan  Kwai  Fong  and  Mong  Kok.

HK  private  sector  contracts  faster  in  Aug  as  PMI  falls  to  44. Private  sector  economy  contracted  at  a  faster  pace  in  August  led  by  sharper  declines  in  output  and  new  orders  amid  tighter  social  distancing  restrictions.

HKSAR  government  rejects  emergency  law  rumors. The  authority  said  that  the  Hong  Kong  banking  system  is  robust  and  sound,  and  that  banks  have  sufficient  supply  of  banknotes  to  meet  the  public's  needs.

FM  condemns  the  EU  meddling  in  HK  affairs. The  Ministry  of  Foreign  Affairs  on  Thursday  strongly  rejected  the  European  Parliament's  intervention  in  the  internal  affairs  of  the  HKSAR  and  China.

Xiaomi  'adds  6  more  Chinese  banks'  to  arrange  mega  HK  IPO. Xiaomi  is  the  first  company  to  use  Hong  Kong's  new  rules  to  go  public,  filing  for  what  would  be  the  world's  largest  first-time  share  sale  since  2014.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.26%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  65.99  points,  or  0.26  percent,  to  25,064.36  points.
Carrie  Lam  visits  temporary  air-inflated  laboratories. It  is  the  second  time  Lam  visited  the  laboratories.  Last  month  she  visited  the  facilities  when  they  were  ready.

Higher  voter  turnout  rate  than  2015  expected. Horace  Cheung  Kwok-kwan,  vice-chairman  of  DAB,  hopes  that  more  people  will  come  out  to  cast  votes  and  support  pro-establishment  candidates.

HK  sees  8  new  virus  cases,  tally  reaches  5,087. The  only  new  local  case  was  a  71-old-woman  who  lived  at  an  elderly  care  home  in  Yuen  Long,  a  Centre  for  Health  Protection  official  said.

HKMAO  backs  HK  court  ruling  that  anti-mask  law  constitutional. A  HKMAO  spokesman  said  the  ruling  will  help  the  law-based  governance  of  the  CE  and  the  HKSAR  govt,  especially  in  effectively  maintaining  public  order.

HK  rewards  people  for  handling  of  unrest,  pandemic. The  city's  annual  list  of  honors  and  medal  recipients  put  a  spotlight  on  those  involved  in  the  handling  of  the  social  unrest  and  the  fight  against  virus.

HKSAR  won't  meddle  with  mainland  jurisdiction. It  is  a  well-recognized  legal  principle  that  each  jurisdiction  deals  with  illegal  acts  in  its  area  in  accordance  with  its  own  laws,  HK's  secretary  chief  wrote  in  his  blog.

HKSAR  insurance  market  lures  well-educated  mainland  Chinese. A  growing  band  of  well-educated  young  Chinese  have  chosen  to  sell  insurance  in      Hong  Kong  to  buyers  from  Chinese  mainland  due  to  the  lucrative  pay.

Student  activism  exposes  defects  of  HK  education. Education  experts  have  called  for  a  complete  review  of  textbooks  used  in  HK  schools  to  foster  a  stronger  sense  of  national  identity  among  students.

Labor  group  furious  after  gala  scrapped  due  to  violence. The  Hong  Kong  Federation  Trade  Union's  National  Day  celebration  was  canceled  after  rioters  instigated  violent  confrontations  on  Sept  29.

HK  lawyers  group  head:  Political  disputes  can't  justify  violence. Head  of  an  influential  solicitors’  association  in  HK  has  called  on  the  city’s  lawyers  to  break  their  silence  to  speak  up  against  the  violent  protests.
Major  tunnel  of  HK-Zhuhai-Macao  Bridge  completed. The  55-kilometer  Hong  Kong-Zhuhai-Macao  Bridge  will  be  the  world's  longest  sea  bridge.

Teacher  deregistered  for  using  pro-independence  materials. A  registered  primary  school  teacher  has  been  barred  from  teaching  after  being  found  to  have  intentionally  advocated  separatism  through  teaching  materials.

CE's  speech  at  reception  marking  HK's  return  to  motherland. Carrie  Lam  delivered  a  speech  at  a  reception  held  in  celebration  of  the  23rd  anniversary  of  the  establishment  of  the  HKSAR  on  Wednesday  morning.

HK  gives  conditional  nod  to  COVID-19  drug  remdesivir. Gilead  Sciences  medicine  remdesivir  has  received  a  conditional  green  light  to  be  used  to  curb  the  coronavirus  pandemic,  Hong  Kong  officials  said.

HK  Government  House  to  remain  open  to  public  March  17. From  10  am  to  5  pm,  there  will  be  guided  tours  on  the  history  and  architectural  features  of  the  distinguished  building.
CE  regrets  Q&A  suspension  after  LegCo  chaos. LegCo  president,  lawmakers  condemn  opposition  antics  as  rude  and  uncivilized.

China  lodges  representation  with  EU  over  'HK  motion'. A  spokesperson  for  the  Chinese  Mission  to  the  EU  has  called  on  the  European  Parliament  to  stop  interfering  in  affairs  of  the  HKSAR.

Losing  money,  Cathay  says  business  outlook  'very  bleak'. Cathay  said  passenger  numbers  in  April  dropped  by  99.6%  compared  to  the  prior  year  due  to  a  ban  on  transit  traffic  in  HK  and  little  outbound  demand.
Collaboration  ‘enhances  both  sides’  strengths’. Ex-CUHK  head  says  HK  has  solid  international  exposure,  while  mainland  researchers  have  access  to  a  much  larger  pool.

Hong  Kong  hotels  in  crisis  as  protests  deter  mainland  visitors. A  HK  lawmaker  representing  the  tourism  industry  foresees  revenue  from  room  sales  plunging  as  much  as  50%  this  month.

Highlights  of  press  briefing  on  national  security  law  for  HK. The  State  Council  Information  Office  held  a  press  conference  about  the  law  of  safeguarding  national  security  in  Hong  Kong  on  Wednesday  morning.

HK  unrest:  Swiss  paper  reveals  biased  reporting  by  US  media. The  Zurich-based  Neue  Zürcher  Zeitung  has  revealed  how  The  New  York  Times  and  CNN  used  a  double  standard  in  their  reporting  about  the  protests  in  HK.

Liaison  chief  urges  society  to  work  for  brighter  future. Wang  Zhimin  stresses  importance  of  city's  prosperity,  nation's  rejuvenation  and  successful  implementation  of  'one  country,  two  systems'.
Lenovo  dropped  from  Hang  Seng  Index. The  Beijing-based  company  will  be  replaced  by  CSPC  Pharmaceutical  Group,  as  part  of  Hang  Seng  Indexes  Co’s  quarterly  review.

HK  economic  growth  slowest  in  10  years. First-quarter  GDP  expanded  to  a  revised  0.6%  compared  with  a  year  ago,  slower  than  growth  of  1.2%  in  the  final  quarter  of  last  year,  according  to  a  govt  report.

Rapid  transit  'offers  chance  to  bring  visitors  into  bay  area'. A  business  group  urged  city  cluster  to  attract  some  of  the  15  million  foreign  visitors  who  come  through  Hong  Kong  annually.
Michael  Lunn  to  head  panel  to  review  bus  franchise. The  committee  will  review  laws,  regulatory  system  and  operation  of  bus  franchise,  and  make  safety  recommendations.
National  Security  Law  puts  patriotism  on  right  course. A  high  school  headmaster  in  HK  said  the  new  law  will  ensure  the  school  continues  its  long-standing  patriotic  tradition.

Don't  interfere  in  HK's  visa  matters,  foreign  govts  told. No  country  has  the  right  to  interfere  in  the  HK  govt's  handling  of  visa  matters  as  the  issue  falls  within  China's  sovereignty,  the  Commissioner's  Office  said.

HK  horse  race  canceled  due  to  social  unrest  concerns. The  canceled  race  was  due  to  the  imminent  threat  to  the  safety  of  racegoers,  jockeys  and  staff,  according  to  the  Hong  Kong  Jockey  Club's  statement.

HK  readying  Chapter  11-style  bankruptcy  system. The  government  hoped  to  introduce  a  bill  setting  out  the  new  arrangements  in  early  2021  at  the  next  LegCo  session  after  the  Sept  election,  an  official  said.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.10%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  27.49  points,  or  0.10  percent,  to  28,171.33  points.
HK  stocks  edge  higher. The  Hang  Seng  index  rose  0.1  percent,  to  28,256.12  points,  while  the  China  Enterprises  Index  gained  0.5  percent,  to  10,731.36  points.

Hong  Kong  insurance  sales  to  mainland  clients  slide  18%. The  purchases  of  insurance  and  related  investment  policies  by  mainland  clients  fell  to  HK$9.7  billion  in  the  third  quarter,  said  Hong  Kong’s  Insurance  Authority.
HK  Disneyland  sees  HK$105m  net  loss  from  social  unrest. Attendance  at  the  theme  park  dropped  4  percent  in  2019  to  6.5  million.

Tourism  business  yet  to  see  light  at  the  end  of  the  tunnel. HK's  tourism  sector  is  likely  to  see  its  "chilly  winter"  persist  in  September  with  the  continued  slump  in  visitor  numbers,  according  to  industry  players.

HK-Shandong  'brotherly  ties'  drive  cooperation. HK's  Chief  Secretary  for  Administration  Matthew  Cheung  Kin-chung  said  the  city  "aims  to  take  the  cooperation  with  Shandong  to  a  new  height."

Hong  Kong's  property  market  takes  hit  from  Cathay  job  cuts. Vacancies  for  apartments  in  Discovery  Bay  and  Tung  Chung,  both  areas  popular  among  Cathay  employees,  have  been  rising  while  rental  prices  have  dropped.
Hong  Kong's  youngsters  seek  to  make  their  mark  on  mainland. Hong  Kong  youths  are  more  eager  to  head  north  to  explore  opportunities  and  carve  out  their  careers.

Civic  leaders  slam  US  sanctions  as  barbarous,  hegemonic. Political  heavyweights  condemned  the  US  over  its  latest  sanctions  on  the  city,  saying  the  "barbarous"  move  was  made  as  an  attempt  to  contain  China's  rise.

Yuan  IPO  in  Hong  Kong  may  raise  cash  for  Belt,  Road. The  govt  is  considering  giving  a  green  light  to  top  firms  involved  in  the  B&R  to  raise  funds  through  a  yuan-dominated  IPO  in  the  HK  stock  exchange.

RISE  stresses  China’s  growing  global  role  in  technology. Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  told  attendees  that  she  is  bullish  about  Hong  Kong’s  role  in  innovation  and  technology  development.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.68%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  473.08  points,  or  1.68  percent,  to  28,561.0  points.

HK  CE  invites  young  people  for  talks  following  pledge  to  be  open. Lam's  invitations  were  extended  to  young  people  of  different  backgrounds,  including  university  students  and  people  who  have  participated  in  recent  protests.

2018  World  Book  Day  Fest  opens  with  joy  and  fun. Hong  Kong  Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  gave  away  some  130  books  chosen  from  her  personal  collection  to  participants  to  share  with  them  the  joy  of  reading.

National  security  law  requires  better  understanding. A  senior  legislator  called  for  legal  professionals  across  the  country  to  closely  study  and  accurately  interpret  the  newly  adopted  national  security  law  for  Hong  Kong.

HKMA  says  deposits  stable  according  to  large  banks'  data. Eddie  Yue  made  the  remarks  after  the  city's  financial  secretary  said  the  People's  Bank  of  China  could  help  HK  defend  the  peg  with  the  US  dollar  if  needed.

AB  InBev  Asia  unit  struggles  to  price  Hong  Kong  IPO. The  company  is  weighing  options  including  relaunching  the  offering  at  a  later  date  with  different  terms,  according  to  people  with  knowledge  of  the  matter.

'Hong  Kong  economic  outlook  worse  than  SARS-hit  2003'. Retail,  catering  and  tourism  industries  have  been  battered  severely  by  the  outbreak  of  the  novel  coronavirus,  said  Financial  Secretary  Paul  Chan  Mo-po.

Govt  calls  for  concerted  efforts  to  curb  spread  of  virus. The  govt  called  for  concerted  efforts  from  the  public  to  stop  the  spread  of  the  novel  coronavirus  pneumonia  as  the  city  reported  six  more  cases.

Junlebao  said  to  weigh  dual  listing  in  HK,  mainland. The  dairy  product  maker  based  in  Hebei  province  could  seek  at  least  US$700  million  in  a  Hong  Kong  share  sale,  one  person  familiar  with  the  matter  said.

Liaison  Office  director:  Security  law  a  'guardian'  for  HK  residents. The  promulgation  of  the  national  security  law  marks  a  significant  turning  point  for  HK  and  a  milestone  for  "one  country,  two  systems,"  said  Luo  Huining.

HK  entrepreneurs  look  for  inspiration  in  Israel. Israel  will  host  16  Hong  Kong  enterprises  which  will  embark  on  a  five-day  business  tour  to  the  country  later  this  month  to  seek  partners  and  inspiration.

Hong  Kong  nurse  says  ready  to  help  combat  virus  in  Wuhan. Trish,  an  experienced  Hong  Kong  nurse,  said  she  is  ready  to  head  to  Wuhan,  the  epicenter  and  hardest-hit  city  in  central  China,  to  give  a  helping  hand.

DAB  announces  55  candidates  for  ‘decisive’  LegCo  polls. Hong  Kong's  largest  political  party,  DAB,  called  the  September  Legislative  Council  election  a  “decisive  battle”  that  could  affect  Hong  Kong's  future.

Foreign  Ministry  reiterates  support  for  rendition  bill. The  central  govt  will  continue  to  support  the  Hong  Kong  SAR  govt  in  amending  the  city's  extradition  laws,  the  foreign  ministry's  spokesman  said.

When  it  comes  to  returns,  HK's  IPO  market  is  living  it  up. There  have  been  12  offerings  above  US$100m  raising  a  total  of  US$2.2b  in  2019,  compared  with  four  deals  for  US$2.1b  in  the  same  period  last  year.

Govt  surveys:  HK  continues  to  attract  multinationals,  start-ups. The  surveys  were  jointly  conducted  by  InvestHK,  an  investment-promoting  department  of  the  HKSAR  govt  and  the  Census  and  Statistics  Department.

Record  Hong  Kong  peg  defense  boosts  liquidity  to  US$58  billion. The  HKMA  sold  a  record  HK$31.8  billion  worth  of  local  dollars  to  curb  the  currency's  strength,  lifting  the  interbank  liquidity  pool  to  almost  HK$450  billion.

Singapore  home  minister  sees  'no  profit'  from  HK  instability. Singapore  Home  Minister  K  Shanmugam  doesn't  believe  the  island  city-state  stands  to  benefit  from  any  instability  in  HK  as  protests  entered  their  3rd  month.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.45%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  112.49  points,  or  0.45  percent,  to  25,007.6  points  on  Thursday.

Hong  Kong’s  dollar  suffers  sudden  bout  of  weakness. Late  on  Friday,  the  currency  weakened  rapidly  in  its  biggest  drop  since  mid-June.  The  decline  was  unexpected,  given  persistent  inflows  into  HK.

Govt,  social  groups  race  against  time  to  get  children’s  masks. DAB  member  Li  Sai-wing  said  once  schools  reopen,  parents  will  have  to  supply  50  to  60  pieces  per  child  every  month,  adding  to  the  burden  of  parents.

Tourism  suffers  as  protesters  extend  blockade  at  airport. Massive  sit-ins  force  scrapping  of  scores  of  tour  groups.  Asia's  financial  center  is  feeling  a  worse-than-expected  chilling  effect  on  its  economy.

Hong  Kong  ranked  most  expensive  city  for  luxuries. Hong  Kong  was  cited  frequently  in  a  report  by  Julius  Baer  in  the  top  10  most  expensive  municipalities  for  categories  such  as  fine  dining  and  luxury.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.27%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  355.71  points,  or  1.27  percent,  to  28,341.04  points.

Companies  around  the  world  get  hit  by  HK  protests. An  AI  model  trained  by  Bloomberg  News    revealed  that  the  city's  protests  are  pressuring  companies  that  sell  all  kinds  of  consumer  goods.

HK,  Chinese  mainland  pledge  further  collaboration  on  BRI  policy. HK,  mainland  officials  vow  to  make  concerted  efforts  to  foster  collaboration  on  policy  exchanges  and  capacity  building  related  to  the  Belt  and  Road  Initiative.

HK  role  as  gateway,  important  hub  showcased  at  CIIE. Hong  Kong  displays  its  strengths,  key  infrastructure  projects,  tourist  attractions,  and  innovation  and  technology  products  and  inventions.

Top  Glove  'hires  banks  for  potential  US$1b  HK  listing’. Malaysian  rubber  glove  maker  Top  Glove,  riding  a  wave  of  demand  generated  by  the  pandemic,  is  said  to  have  hired  banks  to  arrange  an  HK  listing.
Campus  never  shelter  for  law-breakers:  Police. Kong  Wing-cheung  said  police  is  allowed  by  law  to  enter  a  campus  to  enforce  the  law  even  without  search  warrants.

Security  legislation  needed  in  Hong  Kong,  Lam  says. Carrie  Lam  and  high-level  officials  are  to  visit  Beijing  Wednesday  to  offer  views  on  the  proposed  legislation  being  drafted  by  the  Standing  Committee  of  the  NPC.

HK's  love  affair  with  real  estate  endures  even  in  tough  times. Hong  Kong  is  showing  that  its  affinity  for  real  estate  has  been  unaffected  by  a  year  of  anti-government  protests  and  concerns  over  the  coronavirus.

Spokesperson:  Central  govt  supports  arrest  of  crime  suspects. A  central  govt  spokesperson  expressed  support  for  the  arrest  of  15  criminal  suspects  including  Jimmy  Lai  &  Martin  Lee  by  Hong  Kong  police.
Deloitte  proposes  tax  relief  as  fiscal  reserves  swell. Advisory  firm  suggests  making  capital  and  interest  payments  on  mortgages  deductible  from  salaries  tax.

HK  biomedical  expert  wins  'Oscars  of  Science'. HK  biomedical  expert  Dennis  Lo  Yuk-ming  received  a  2021  Breakthrough  Prize  in  Life  Sciences  for  his  contributions  to  non-invasive  prenatal  diagnoses.

HK  private  sector  sentiment  slips  to  nearly  3-year  low. The  seasonally  adjusted  headline  Nikkei  Hong  Kong  purchasing  managers  index  (PMI)  fell  from  48.4  in  April  to  46.9  in  May,  its  lowest  level  since  June  2016.
Scientist:  Bay  Area  sci-tech  bond  capable  of  global  achievements. CAS  member  says  China  is  doing  right  things  to  nurture  future  scientific  breakthroughs  of  global  significance.
Disconnected,  marooned  in  a  world  of  their  own. People  with  autism  feel  rejected,  struggling  to  communicate  with  the  world  around  them.

E-commerce:  Tackling  markets  and  cultures. E-commerce  professional  Alan  Lim  knows  the  business  well  after  more  than  10  years  in  the  game.  He  is  focused  on  emerging  markets  and  avoids  those  where  the  giants  are.

Lam  refutes  resignation  talk,  vows  to  serve  public. Speaking  to  reporters  ahead  of  the  weekly  Executive  Council  meeting,  Lam  stressed  that  she  never  even  contemplated  resigning.

HK  youths  urged  to  seize  inno-tech  opportunities. Deputy  liaison  chief  tells  summer  interns  central  government  support  and  city's  innovation  drive  have  created  perfect  opportunity.

Hang  Seng  Index  plunges  5.12%  after  Wall  St  slumps. Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  Cheng  Yuet-ngor  reminded  investors  to  be  cautious  as  the  stock  market  became  volatile  from  time  to  time.

HK  tycoon  makes  US$3.3b  bet  pubs  will  survive  Brexit. CK  Asset  has  agreed  to  pay  2.7  billion  pounds  (US$3.3  billion)  for  Greene  King,  which  operates  more  than  2,700  British  bars,  restaurants  and  hotels.

53  nations  join  to  welcome  national  security  law  for  HK. The  countries  said  in  a  joint  statement  that  the  new  legislation  will  provide  a  better  guarantee  for  "one  country,  two  systems".

Carrie  Lam:  Tackling  housing  'first  step'  to  end  impasse. Hong  Kong  CE  Carrie  Lam  refuted  claims  on  Thursday  that  her  Policy  Address  is  aimed  at  diverting  public  attention  from  the  current  political  impasse.
Tycoons  dismayed  over  recent  violence. Some  of  HK's  most  prominent  business  magnates  warned  that  the  city's  global  reputation  has  suffered  after  the  violent  attack  on  LegCo.
HK's  first  military  base  finds  new  life  as  therapy  center. Historic  soldiers'  accommodation  in  Admiralty  is  set  for  transformation  under  the  government's  revitalization  scheme.

HK  home  prices  up  0.4%  in  March,  but  pressure  remains. Agents  said  strong  pent-up  demand  and  low  interest  rates  will  give  some  support  to  the  market,  and  the  transaction  volume  continued  to  recover  in  April.

Analysts:  HK  exports  expected  to  rise  in  2019  despite  Nov  drop. The  city's  volume  of  export  orders  fell  in  the  second  half  of  2018  during  a  period  of  trade  tensions  between  the  mainland  and  the  United  States.

HK  sees  huge  room  for  growth  in  trade  with  Cambodia. Trade  volume  between  HKSAR  and  Cambodia  rose  to  US$1.2  billion  in  2017,  an  average  increase  of  3.1  percent  a  year  since  2013.

HK-ASEAN  free  trade  agreement  effective  on  Oct  20  for  Brunei. Tariff  reduction  commitments  under  the  free  trade  agreement  covers  different  kinds  of  Hong  Kong  commodities,  including  jewelery,  apparel  and  toys.

HK  youth  upbeat  about  working  in  Bay  Area. But  the  survey  also  found  that  many  youngsters  are  hesitant  about  engaging  with  the  region  as  they  are  unsure  about  opportunities  available.
Commercializing  5G  —  ZTE  eyeing  pole  position. ZTE  pulls  out  all  the  stops  in  march  toward  5G  commercialization.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.17%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  50.07  points,  or  0.17  percent,  to  29,936.32  points.
PBOC  to  issue  bills  in  Hong  Kong. Half  of  the  20  billion  renminbi  bills  will  be  issued  in  a  three-month  tenor  and  the  remaining  10  billion  in  a  one-year  tenor.

HK  prepares  for  citywide  virus  testing. ​Hong  Kong's  free  coronavirus  testing  will  begin  on  Sept  1,  as  the  government  races  to  locate  asymptomatic  patients  to  tame  the  latest  outbreak.
Bond  moves  boost  HK’s  hub  credentials. Pundits  hail  city’s  measures  to  spur  bond  market  as    the  right  step  for  a  comprehensive  financial  center.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.73%  lower. The  benchmark  Hang  Seng  Index  traded  between  23,895.03  and  24,317.72.  Turnover  totaled  about  US$14.90  billion.

HK  next  up  in  world's  growing  list  of  stock  bear  markets. Hong  Kong  stocks  staved  off  entering  its  second  bear  market  in  as  many  years  on  Thursday,  with  the  Hang  Seng  Index  closing  down  3.7%.
Political  academy  puts  spotlight  on  ethics. Noting  a  deteriorating  political  climate,  patron  Ronny  Tong  says  city  needs  to  cultivate  good  leaders.

HK  residents  may  get  a  break  over  national  tax  law. Secretary  for  Financial  Services  and  the  Treasury  ​James  Lau  says  HK  people  living  on  the  mainland  may  only  need  to  pay  income  tax  on  part  of  their  earnings.

Mong  Kok  rioter  denied  leave  to  appeal. Yeung  Ka-lun,  33,  was  sentenced  to  four  years  and  nine  months  in  jail  last  year  for  his  role  in  setting  a  taxi  on  fire  during  the  Mong  Kok  riot.

HK  justice  chief  allays  concerns  on  proposed  security  law. The  Chinese  mainland  and  the  HKSAR  share  fundamental  principles  safeguarding  national  security,  said  the  city's  justice  chief  Teresa  Cheng.
HK  govt  advises  against  family  gatherings. Infections  spike  following  nine  confirmed  cases  linked  to  a  reunion  meal  of  19  people.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.22%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  335.62  points,  or  1.22  percent,  to  27,843.71  points.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.82%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  219.47  points,  or  0.82  percent,  to  26,566.73  points.

Lam  'most  impressed'  by  strong  support. The  central  govt's  support  could  also  be  seen  in  its  efforts  to  back  Hong  Kong's  participation  in  different  national  development  blueprints,  Lam  said.

Blueprint  for  Bay  Area  development  to  be  unveiled. The  blueprint  is  expected  to  outline  broad  guidelines  to  transform  Guangdong-HK-Macao  Greater  Bay  Area  into  a  global  economic  power  house.

Key  alliance  set  up  to  promote  innovation  in  Bay  Area. An  alliance  was  jointly  established  in  Guangzhou  by  top  scientists  and  engineers  from  Guangdong  province,  Hong  Kong  and  Macao.

HK  port  cargo  throughput  down  8.2%  in  2018. Hong  Kong  port  handled  19.60  million  TEUs  of  containers,  down  5.7%  from  2017,  and  the  number  of  ocean  vessels  arrivals  went  down  5.2%  to  25,410.
The  'new  economy'  takes  the  floor. Asia's  leading  stock  exchanges  swing  into  top  gear  with  groundbreaking  listing  overhauls  to  lure  tech  enterprises.

HK  reports  4  new  COVID-19  cases,  tally  at  1,033. Hong  Kong  recorded  four  new  COVID-19  cases  on  Wednesday  –  all  returnees  from  the  United  Kingdom  –  taking  the  local  tally  to  1,033.
Forum  calls  for  enhanced  cooperation  among  bay  areas. An  international  forum  on  cooperation  and  development  among  major  global  bay  areas  was  held  in  San  Francisco  on  Friday.

Police:  Firing  warning  shot  'necessary'. Assistant  commissioner  of  police  said  officer  who  fired  one  warning  shot  into  the  air  on  Aug  25  acted  in  self-defense  in  a  "life-or-death"  situation.

Tours  to  Australia  canceled  to  avoid  mandatory  quarantine. Thousands  of  tourists  are  affected  by  the  cancellation  of  tours  to  Australia  due  to  a  change  of  the  country's  entry  policy.

Filmmakers  rule  out  online  film  festival. Filmmakers  are  convinced  that  holding  a  film  festival  online  will  not  work,  according  to  the  head  of  the  renowned  Hong  Kong  International  Film  Festival.

HK  government  to  hold  legal  summit  on  Basic  Law. With  the  theme  of  "Back  to  Basic,"  the  summit  is  aimed  at  enhancing  the  public's  understanding  of  the  Constitution  and  the  HKSAR  Basic  Law.
SAR  govt:  No  foreign  interference  allowed. Spokesman  dismisses  US  report's  'biased  conclusions  and  unfounded  accusations'

China  firmly  opposes  US  visa  curbs  on  Chinese  officials. ​China  strongly  opposes  the  US  imposing  visa  restrictions  on  Chinese  officials  over  HK-related  issues,  a  spokesperson  for  the  Chinese  embassy  in  the  US  said.

Hong  Kong  gets  zero  fee  trading  in  blow  to  struggling  brokers. As  of  last  month,  Huatai  International  is  no  longer  charging  commissions  and  platform  fees  for  stock  trades,  but  just  a  HK$8  monthly  fee.

Virus:  HK  sees  4  new  infections,  all  linked  to  overseas  travel. The  government  is  considering  tighter  quarantine  measures  for  arrivals  from  the  US  and  the  US  amid  rising  imported  cases  of  infection,  said  health  officials.

National  security  law  requires  better  understanding. A  senior  legislator  called  for  legal  professionals  across  the  country  to  closely  study  and  accurately  interpret  the  newly  adopted  national  security  law  for  Hong  Kong.

Experts:  'Misleading'  to  call  12  fugitives  'democracy  activists'. Hong  Kong  legal  experts  said  the  12  HK  fugitives  detained  by  mainland  authority  are  guaranteed  due  process  of  law  and  of  having  their  rights  protected.

HKSAR  govt  rebuts  fallacious  comments  on  virus  testing. HK  govt  expressed  regret  over  the  false  information  on  the  internet  and  social  media  platforms  about  the  universal  community  testing  program.

Tang  determined  to  make  mark  on  LegCo  for  NT  East. Former  LegCo  member  Bill  Tang  Ka-piu  is  confident  he  can  win  support  from  voters  in  big  geographical  constituency  by  addressing  a  range  of  issues.

Listings  rush  could  take  HK  to  back  into  top-three  globally. EY  is  bullish  on  IPO  outlook  in  HK  and  the  mainland  following  strong  first  half  as  policy  changes  are  likely  to  attract  launches.
HK  confirms  3  new  infections,  1  more  patient  discharged. The  latest  cases  brought  the  tally  of  confirmed  coronavirus  infection  in  Hong  Kong  to  65.

Stabbing  of  HK  lawmaker  condemned. Central  authorities  in  charge  of  Hong  Kong  affairs  voiced  strong  condemnation  over  the  stabbing  of  a  HK  lawmaker,  calling  it  a  violent  attempt  to  influence  polls.
NPC  deputy  and  businessman  Peter  Wong  dies. The  70-year-old  fell  ill  in  Beijing  and  transferred  to  HK  for  treatment  before  passing  away  on  March  11.
Jockey  Club  makes  record  charity  donations. Hong  Kong  Jockey  Club  has  made  a  record  charity  and  community  donation  to  the  tune  of  HK$4.3  billion  to  support  294  projects.
Hong  Kong  stocks  strike  10-day  rising  streak. At  close  of  trade,  the  Hang  Seng  index  was  up  84.89  points  or  0.28  percent  at  30,899.53.

Justice  chief  blasts  foreign  forces  for  'groundless'  remarks. HK's  justice  chief  slammed  foreign  politicians  for  making  false  accusations  against  the  arrests  and  prosecutions  of  15  prominent  opposition  figures.

Hong  Kong  IPOs  are  at  their  hottest  since  2015. HK  is  set  to  surpass  2018  in  fundraising  for  first-time  share  sales  as  so  far,  it  is  just  US$200m  short  of  last  year's  total  -  which  itself  was  the  highest  since  2010.
Experts  decry  lenient  sentence  for  flag  defilement. Community  service  sentence  ignores  seriousness  of  flag  desecrating  offender's  crime,  legal  experts  say.

HK  currency  intervention  nears  US$1b  as  more  seen. HKMA  has  spent  HK$7.4b  this  month  buying  local  dollars  as  low  interest  rates  make  the  currency  less  attractive  to  hold  compared  with  the  greenback  and  yuan.

Home  quarantine  challenges  families. Elderly  couple  express  their  gratitude  to  the  volunteers,  social  workers  and  govt  officers  who  helped  to  ease  the  stress  of  two  week  of  challenges.
HK  government  warns  against  non-essential  trips  to  Sri  Lanka. The  alert  comes  after  recent  bomb  attacks  killed  and  wounded  hundreds  in  Sri  Lanka.
HK  to  gradually  restore  public  services  from  May  4. Some  public  facilities,  such  as  outdoor  sports  grounds,  libraries,  and  museums  will  reopen,  starting  Monday.
Violence  and  vandalism  disrupt  travelers  and  residents  alike. MTR  operations  director  strongly  condemns  destruction  by  protesters  at  city  railway  stations.

Withdrawal  of  extradition  bill  paves  way  for  dialogue,  Lam  says. Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  reiterated  that  there  would  be  no  voting  or  debate  when  it  comes  to  the  withdrawal  of  the  extradition  bill.
Reporters  urged  to  respect  each  other  after  row  at  briefing. Hong  Kong  police  on  Wednesday  called  on  journalists  to  respect  each  other's  freedom  to  report  news.

Spare  the  rod. Recent  fatalities  have  blown  the  lid  off  pervasive  child  abuse  in  HK.  China  Daily  takes  a  look  at  how  deep  the  malaise  runs  and  what  is  being  done  to  stem  it.

Luo  Huining  appointed  director  of  Liaison  Office  in  HKSAR. The  State  Council  on  Saturday  appointed  Luo  Huining  as  Director  of  the  Liaison  Office  of  the  Central  People's  Government  in  the  HKSAR.
HK  charting  rare  chapters  in  nation’s  70-year  development. Hong  Kong  has  been  known  for  generations  as  the  place  where  East  meets  West.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.49%  lower. The  benchmark  Hang  Seng  Index  traded  between  24,258.56  and  24,678.9.  Turnover  totaled  HK$133.19  billion  (about  US$17.19  billion).
Wang  encourages  HK  youths  to  contribute  to  national  development. Liaison  chief  stresses  vital  role  of  young  people  in  both  nation's  past  and  exciting  future.

HK  police  strongly  condemn  violence,  attacks  on  officers. A  Hong  Kong  police  officer  fired  a  warning  shot  on  Friday  after  officers  were  attacked  by  protesters  in  Yau  Ma  Tei.
Punish  teachers  spreading  hateful  messages. The  Education  Bureau  strongly  criticized  two  teachers  who  disseminated  hateful  anti-police  messages  on  social  media.

More  HK  patients  confirmed  aboard  Diamond  Princess. The  tally  reaches  50  as  passengers  of  the  cruise  liner  docked  in  Japan  undergo  medical  checks  to  determine  if  they  can  fly  home  on  board  flights  chartered  by  the  government.
HK  to  launch  online  dispute  resolution  platform. Digital  mediation,  arbitration  solution  part  of  city's  bid  to  become  global  conciliation  center,  Carrie  Lam  says.

Hong  Kong  Disneyland  loses  right  to  land  near  theme  park. The  Hong  Kong  government  won’t  extend  the  20-year  purchase  option,  which  expires  Thursday  due  to  "the  current  economic  condition".
45  charged  after  Sunday's  violent  clashes. Of  those  arrested,  44  will  be  charged  for  rioting,  with  a  33-year-old  man  additionally  charged  with  assaulting  police  officers.

HK$30b  relief  fund  gets  an  overwhelming  nod. Lawmakers  passed  the  government’s  HK$30  billion  epidemic  relief  package  after  a  marathon  10-hour  meeting  of  the    Finance  Committee  on  Friday.
HSBC:  HK  property  awash  in  cash  shielded  from  rates. HSBC  has  been  warning  that  rising  interest  rates  could  wreak  havoc  on  the  world's  priciest  property  market.

Ko  deplores  illegal  storming  of  the  Legislative  Council  building. Former  secretary  for  food  and  health  Ko  Wing-man  suspects  foreign  intervention  in  violent  protests,  attacks  by  demonstrators.

Risk  of  local  outbreak  seen  as  7  new  cases  linked  to  foreign  travel. HK  authorities  warned  about  a  second  round  of  coronavirus  outbreak,  after  7  cases  of  infection  were  reported  -  all  linked  to  overseas  travel.
Hundreds  of  fans  ride  first  train  of  new  line. Three  new  stations  on  the  new  Tuen  Ma  Line  -  Hin  Keng,  Diamond  Hill  and  Kai  Tak  -  opened  for  service  on  Friday.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.88%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  448.81  points,  or  1.88  percent,  to  24,280.14  points.

Sogo  sees  business  battered  as  protests  go  on. Hong  Kong's  escalating  anti-extradition  protests  have  taken  their  toll  on  the  operator  of  the  city's  biggest  Japanese-style  department  store  chain,  Sogo.
UK  urged  to  rectify  BN(O)  visa  policy. Using  passport  as  a  citizenship  pathway  violates  HK  pre-handover  agreement.

An  ‘Indian  summer’  in  a  hardy  market. HK  had  seen  ups  and  downs  in  the  property  sector,  and  the  latest  setback  may  not  be  a  harbinger  of  anything  worse  to  come.  Experts  see  it  as  just  a  ‘hold  on’  game  for  potential  buyers.

Liaison  office  backs  HK  police  move  to  ensure  peaceful  holidays. The  liaison  office  reaffirmed  its  support  in  a  statement  after  some  social  groups  issued  a  call  to  wreak  havoc  across  the  city  during  the  upcoming  holidays.
Hong  Kong  stocks  pare  gains  as  weak  mainland  economic  data  bites. The  Hang  Seng  index  ended  up  0.1%  at  25,302.28,  while  the  China  Enterprises  Index  gained  0.2%  to  9,866.18.

HKEX  chief:  Unrest  will  hinder  city's  development. Road  ahead  remains  rough  as  the  Sino-US  trade  spat  has  slowed  the  HK’s  economy,  and  market  sentiment  has  been  dampened  by  the  demonstrations.

HK  foreign  currency  reserve  assets  up  in  January. The  city's  official  foreign  currency  reserve  assets  amounted  to  US$432  billion  at  the  end  of  January  from  US$424.7  billion  in  the  previous  month.

Next  time,  you  won't  be  just  staring  at  empty  machines. HK  startup  Gritus  provides  machines  which  can  warn  companies  that  supplies  have  run  out,  or  are  fast  running  out,  so  that  they  can  be  quickly  restocked.

Lam:  University  league  to  boost  HK's  ties  with  Shanghai. Carrie  Lam  said  the  Shanghai-Hong  Kong  University  Alliance  has  the  potential  to  serve  the  world's  second-largest  economy  by  making  contributions.

Police  appeal  to  protesters  not  to  obstruct  sending  injured  visitor  to  hospital. Police  call  for  demonstrators  to  stop  obstruction  of  medical  assistance  for  a  visitor  assaulted  and  besieged  at  HK  airport.
DAB  seeks  mainland  ID  cards  for  HK  residents. Delegation  from  party  proposes  measures  to  improve  living  conditions  for  cross-boundary  dwellers  in  Guangdong.
HK  deputies,  advisers  called  on  to  support  bill. Amendments  have  full  support  of  central  government:  Wang

Carrie  Lam:  Report  on  protests  fair,  objective  and  factually  based. Lam  said  the  government  would  form  a  task  force  under  the  Security  Bureau  to  follow  up  suggestions  by  the  Independent  Police  Complaints  Council.

Central  govt  voices  firm  support  for  HK's  ban  on  separatist  group. The  Hong  Kong  and  Macao  Affairs  Office  of  the  State  Council  said  it  resolutely  supports  the  HKSAR  govt's  ban  on    the  so-called  "Hong  Kong  National  Party."

HK  residents  petition  for  tearing  off  rioters'  'masks'. Thousands  of  residents  signed  a  petition  on  Thursday,  calling  for  the  govt  to  draft  a  bill  against  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  haiwainet.cn  reported.
Bridge  project  puts  Chinese  engineering  on  global  map. HZMB  chief  engineer  sees  innovative  techniques  used  to  construct  massive  link  being  deployed  in  B&R  ventures.

Educating  HK  public  about  national  security  law  'crucial'. ​National  legislators  and  political  advisers  in  HK  have  highlighted  the  importance  of  strengthening  education  on  and  promoting  the  national  security  law.

New  customs  rule  to  hit  HK-US  mail. From  June  1,  items  sent  to  the  US  from  Hong  Kong,  except  small  &  large  letters,  must  have  English  electronic  customs  information  at  the  time  of  posting.

Senior  CPC  official  meets  Hong  Kong  police  commissioner. Guo  Shengkun  expressed  the  hope  that  the  Hong  Kong  police  will  strengthen  their  faith  and  continue  to  crack  down  on  violent  and  criminal  activities.

Hong  Kong  cuts  base  rate  following  Fed’s  emergency  move. The  HKMA  on  Wednesday  lowered  its  base  rate  to  1.50  percent  from  2.00  percent  in  step  with  the  Fed’s  move  according  to  a  “pre-set  formula”.
Hong  Kong  police  visit  Beijing  for  anniversary. On  Monday  morning,  Hong  Kong  police  sergeant  Lau  Chak-kei  finally  realized  his  dream  of  climbing  the  Great  Wall  in  Beijing.

HK  police  condemn  'rapidly  escalating'  violence. The  police  noted  that  with  the  escalating  violence,  the  safety  of  police  officers  and  other  members  of  the  public  was  under  serious  threat.

HK  chief  executive  vows  greatest  resolve  to  end  violence. In  a  televised  speech  on  Saturday,  Carrie  Lam  said  the  extreme  violence  on  Friday  night  had  clearly  demonstrated  that  HK's  public  safety  is  under  extensive  threats.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  1.73%  lower. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  down  480.88  points,  or  1.73  percent,  to  27,308.46  points.

HK  retail  sales  down  for  19th  consecutive  month. Hong  Kong's  retail  sales  fell  13.1  percent  in  August  from  a  year  ago  –  down  for  the  19th  consecutive  month  --  as  the  coronavirus  pandemic  raged  on.

Cathay  Pacific  to  lay  off  overseas  cabin  crew,  furlough  pilots. In  a  statement,  Cathay  said  it  was  communicating  with  the  affected  crew  in  New  York,  San  Francisco  and  Los  Angeles  as  well  as  their  union.

Unauthorized  rally  turns  radical  in  Hong  Kong. Demonstrators  have  defied  a  police  ban  to  a  take  part  in  a  rally  in  Yuen  Long  to  pressure  the  government  to  meet  their  demands  on  Saturday.

Activist  arrested  on  child  abuse  charges. An  opposition  activist,  James  Lung  Wai-man,  was  arrested  on  Friday  on  suspicion  of  molesting  children  and  distributing  child  pornography.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.13%  higher. The  benchmark  Hang  Seng  Index  traded  between  24,556.55  and  24,817.01.  Turnover  totaled  HK$107.18  billion  (about  US$13.83  billion).

HK  police:  Standard  procedure  used  in  handling  detainees. The  HK  police​  reiterated  that  they  have  a  set  of  standard  procedures  in  handling  persons  in  police  custody,  as  well  as  stringent  guidelines  for  the  use  of  force.

Public  urged  not  to  participate  in  unapproved  protests. HK  govt  appeals  to  the  public  not  to  take  part  in  unsanctioned  processions  on  the  coming  Tuesday,  for  the  sake  of  safety  and  morality.
Public  servants'  illegal  action  will  not  be  tolerated. Civil  service  secretary  regrets  some  staff  arrested  on  suspicion  of  involvement  in  unlawful  activities.

HK  CE,  govt  officials  welcome  passage  of  national  security  law. Lam  said  the  enactment  of  a  national  security  law  at  the  state  level  is  both  necessary  and  urgent  in  order  to  plug  the  loophole  in  national  security  in  HK.
HK  business  backs  national  security  law. Financial  Secretary  Paul  Chan  said  the  city's  financial  sector  believes  the  new  law  will  boost  business  opportunities.
Report  urges  media  to  speed  up  high-tech  transformation. It  reveals  some  journalist  outlets  in  the  city  have  not  yet  reaped  benefits  of  embracing  new  technology.

Observatory  set  to  raise  typhoon  signal  No.  8  over  HK. The  Observatory  said  it  could  raise  the  Gale  or  Storm  Signal  No  8  before  dawn  Tuesday  as  tropical  storm  Nangka  edged  closer  to  the  city.

CGO  staff  tests  negative  for  virus. A  Central  Government  Offices  staff  member  had  been  admitted  to  hospital  after  being  suspected  of  contracting  the  coronavirus,  said  a  HK  govt  spokesman.
Travel  curb  set  to  foreign  countries. All  international  travelers  face  home  quarantine  or  medical  surveillance.

DAB  looks  forward  to  party  building  on  its  recent  achievements. The  DAB  chairman  Starry  Lee  also  said  the  party  is  keen  to  participate  in  the  development  of  Guangzhou-Hong  Kong-Macao  Greater  Bay  Area.
Professor  sentenced  to  life  for  killing  wife,  daughter  in  HK. Jury  finds  Malaysian  professor  guilty  of  murdering  wife  and  daughter  with  lethal  yoga  ball.
63  held  for  causing  chaos  to  MTR  stations. Police  also  seized  a  large  number  of  fake  press  cards  and  detained  six  men  and  two  women  in  a  raid  in  Sai  Wan  Saturday.
Ex-official:  Talk  to  Beijing  for  solutions. Mike  Rowse  advises  protesters  not  to  look  abroad  for  cures  to  Hong  Kong's  problems.

Livestreaming  brings  HK  products  closer  to  mainland  consumers. Six  thousand  boxes  of  mooncakes  sold  in  30  sec,  20,000  cases  of  beauty  masks  snapped  up  in  several  minutes...  the  first  sales  promotion  via  livestreaming  for  products  made  in  HK.

China  to  take  countermeasures  against  US  over  HK-related  act. The  Hong  Kong  and  Macao  Affairs  Office  strongly  condemned  the  signing  of  the  so-called  "Hong  Kong  Autonomy  Act"  into  law  by  the  United  States.

Rioters  take  down  national  flag  from  pole,  attack  police. Rioters  took  down  the  national  flag  from  a  pole  and  attacked  police  officers  in  an  assembly  at  Edinburgh  Place    on  Sunday  afternoon.

Wave  of  selling  hits  HK  stocks  as  some  sink  at  least  70%. Jiayuan  International,  Sunshine  100  and  Rentian  Technology  fell  more  than  75%  in  a  matter  of  minutes  in  the  afternoon  before  market  close.

To  stay  or  quit  —  a  dilemma  for  cross-boundary  pupils,  parents. Distressed  parents  are  considering  taking  their  children  back  to  mainland  schools  after  months  of  social  unrest  in  Hong  Kong  left  pupils  terrorized.

Woman  gets  46  months  in    prison  for  role  in  2016  riot. Pat  Wai-fun,  a  24-year-old  woman  was  sentenced  to  46  months  in  prison  on  Tuesday  on  two  charges  of  rioting  in  Mong  Kok  over  three  years  ago.

Whampoa  Garden  resident  13th  coronavirus  patient  in  HK. The  patient,39,  took  high-speed  rail  train  from  Hong  Kong  to  Wuhan  on  Jan  21  and  from  Changsha  to  Hong  Kong  on  Jan  23.

HK  govt  announces  transport  subsidy  to  be  available  from  Feb. Under  a  Hong  Kong  subsidy  scheme,  every  eligible  commuter's  subsidy  amount  is  25%  of  actual  expenses  above  HK$400  and  is  capped  at  HK$300.
Patients,  families  condemn  medical  strike. People  who  suffered  because  of  the  five-day  strike  staged  by  medical  employees  in  early  February  spoke  out  on  Wednesday.

Hong  Kong  visitor  arrivals  drop  more  than  half  in  January. Hong  Kong's  visitor  arrivals  in  January  more  than  halved  from  a  year  ago  as  cross-border  transport  services  were  reduced  amid  the  coronavirus  outbreak.
HZMB  offers  e-ticketing  service  for  shuttle  bus  users. The  latest  move  aims  to  reduce  the  ongoing  problems  caused  by  excessive  numbers  of  passengers.

HK  experts:  Misleading  to  call  12  fugitives  'democracy  activists’. Legal  experts  and  political  heavyweights  said  it  is  "misleading"  and  factually  unfounded  for    US  politicians  to  call  12  arrested  fugitives  as  "democracy  activists".

Germany  slammed  for  halting  extradition  treaty  with  HKSAR. The  Chinese  Embassy  in  Germany  strongly  opposed  the  wrong  remarks  of  German  Foreign  Minister  Heiko  Maas  regarding  Hong  Kong  affairs.

Attempts  to  interfere  in  HK  legislative  process  deplored. The  Commissioner's  Office  of  the  Foreign  Ministry  in  the  HKSAR  said  it  deplored  the  attempts  by  relevant  countries  to  continuously  interfere  in  the  normal  legislative  process  of  the  HKSAR.

Inquiries  up  in  street-level  shops  on  stability  hopes. Inquiries  for  buying  and  leasing  street-level  shops  have  jumped  since  the  national  security  legislation  was  proposed,  said  realtors.

Envoy  slams  UK  coverage  of  security  law. China's  UK  envoy  said  local  media's  reports  on  the  new  security  law  are  "full  of  misinterpretation,  misunderstanding,  and  even  distortion".

Tourism  to  mainland  holds  steady. Nearly  70  million  visits  were  made  to  the  Chinese  mainland  over  the  past  six  months  while  visits  by  travellers  from  Hong  Kong  dropped  nearly  3%.
HKSAR,  Guangdong  sign  2020  cooperation  work  plan. The  plan  jointly  takes  forward  57  measures  covering  eight  major  areas  on  the  basis  of  complementarity  and  mutual  benefit.

George  Yeo:  US  'undermining  trade  talks'  with  China. Yeo  said  whether  there  will  be  positive  outcomes  from  next  round  of  trade  talk  between  two  countries  depends  much  on  2020  US  presidential  election.

Lam  sets  out  vision  for  HKSAR  as  new-economy  hub. CE  Carrie  Lam  told  the  Internet  Economy  Summit  that  she  would  focus  on  drawing  in  new,  high-growth  industries  at  cutting  edge  of  technology.
Opening  remarks  by  CE  at  media  session. Chief  Executive  Carrie  Lam  met  the  press  at  the  Central  Government  Offices  on  Tuesday.
Shocked  to  the  core!. With  70%  of  Shenzhen  population  living  in  rental  housing,  calls  have  grown  to  rein  in  unscrupulous  intermediaries  amid  complaints  against  deceptions.
HK  High  Court  temporarily  reinstates  mask  ban. The  court’s  decision  came  a  day  after  the  Hong  Kong  government  sought  a  suspension  of  the  ruling  against  the  anti-mask  law.

HK  govt  to  charge  fees  to  discourage  accommodation  abuse. The  HK  govt  will  charge  each  occupant  HK$200  a  day  for  staying  in  temporary  accommodation  to  crack  down  on  the  abuse  of  quarantine  centers.

HK  banks,  developers  offer  sweeteners  after  rate  hike. The  moves  come  after  lenders  in  the  city  last  week  raised  their  best  lending  rates  for  the  first  time  in  more  than  12  years.

Former  NPC  Law  Committee  chief  to  visit  HK. Former  chairman  of  the  NPC  Law  Committee  Qiao  Xiaoyang  will  begin  a  one-week  visit  to  the  city  Thursday  on  invitation  from  the  government.

Lawmakers  urged  to  approve  HK$16b  anti-virus  initiatives. Hong  Kong  residents  on  Friday  called  for  the  Legislative  Council  to  quickly  approve  anti-pandemic  initiatives  involving  HK$16  billion  ($2.1  billion).

HK  chefs  invited  to  Dublin  to  promote  Irish  food  in  China. Finalists  of  a  recently  held  EU-funded  culinary  competition  in  Hong  Kong  will  tour  Ireland  to  get  a  first-hand  impression  of  Irish  foods.

History  center  aims  to  nurture  national  identity. Education  body  seeks  to  encourage  Hong  Kong  young  people  to  be  more  patriotic  and  have  a  better  appreciation  of  Chinese  history.
Hong  Kong  stocks  close  0.74%  higher. Hong  Kong  stocks  closed  up  231.43  points,  or  0.74  percent,  to  31,498.598  points.

Mainland  team  'lays  foundation  for  future  virus  control’. The  selfless  efforts  of  the  mainland  medical  team  to  help  the  city  complete  more  than  1.5  million  tests  have  touched  the  hearts  of  Hong  Kong  people.
